headline: Carne Adovada (New Mexico-Style Pork With Red Chiles) Recipe
description: Similar to chile con carne but made with pork, carne adovada is a New Mexico dish offering perfectly tender chunks of pork shoulder braised in a base made of an assortment of chiles.

video.description: In this video, you'll learn how to make Carne adovada. Carne adovada is a New Mexico-style pork with red chiles. Watch as this southwestern and tex mex pork meal comes together for a tasty dinner. Follow this step-by-step video recipe to make a tasty pork main for dinner in a short amount of time. This recipe is simple and beginner-friendly and makes for a good chili alternative. Watch as this meat main comes together for a warm and savory meal.

name: Carne Adovada (New Mexico-Style Pork With Red Chiles) Recipe
keywords: carne adovada, low carb, New Mexico, pork, The Food Lab
recipeIngredient: 4 whole dried ancho chilies, seeds and stems removed
4 whole dried pasilla chilies, seeds and stems removed
1 quart (32 ounces) homemade or store-bought low-sodium chicken stock
3 whole chipotle chilies canned in adobo
3 pounds boneless pork shoulder, trimmed and cut into 2-inch thick steaks
Corn tortillas, cilantro, diced onions, lime wedges, and queso fresco for serving (optional)

recipeInstructions.text: Add dried chiles to large heavy-bottomed Dutch oven or stock pot and cook over medium-high heat, stirring frequently, until slightly darkened with intense, roasted aroma, 2 to 5 minutes. Do not allow to smoke. Add chicken stock, raisins, orange juice concentrate, chipotles in adobo, white vinegar, and fish sauce. Bring to a boil over high heat, reduce to a bare simmer, and let cook until chiles are totally softened, about 15 minutes. Blend into a smooth puree using an immersion blender or by transferring to a countertop blender. Set aside.

Carefully pat pork cubes dry with paper towels or a clean kitchen towel. Heat vegetable oil in a large heavy-bottomed Dutch oven over high heat until smoking. Add pork all at once and spread evenly over bottom surface. (It's ok if not all the pork is touching the bottom or if the pan is crowded.) Cook without moving until bottom surface is well browned, about 8 minutes. Transfer pork to a cutting board and set aside. Add onions and garlic to Dutch oven and cook, stirring frequently, until softened and beginning to brown, about 10 minutes. Add oregano and cumin and cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 30 seconds.

Add chile mixture to Dutch oven and stir to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom. Add bay leaves along with the pork and any accumulated juices. Bring to a boil then reduce to a bare simmer. Cover, leaving lid slightly ajar, and cook, stirring occasionally until pork chunks break apart when you apply pressure with a spoon, about 2 hours.

Sauce should be thick, with an almost ketchup-like consistency. If too thin, increase heat to a light simmer and cook, stirring frequently, until reduced to the desired consistency. Season to taste with salt.
Serve pork with corn tortillas, cilantro, diced onions, lime wedges, and queso fresco. Pork can be stored in a sealed container in the fridge for up to 5 days.

review.reviewBody:
Can't help but laugh at everyone who is offended by OJ and raisins. If you actually read the food lab article, these are specifically in there to make up for the fact that dried chilies in New York are "a bit dry and dusty" in Kenji's words. Obviously if you are IN New Mexico and have access to the good stuff, you wouldn't add it. That and the fish sauce - you know, unless you add absurd amounts of the stuff you won't actually taste fish flavor. I would recommend trying Food Lab recipes before judging them. 

No one would eat this and think "Hmm. I taste raisins, oranges, and fish. This is wrong!"

I was turned on to Serious Eats and J. Kenji Lopez-Alt by another GREAT recipe for chile verde (https://www.seriouseats.com/easy-pressure-cooker-pork-chile-verde-recipe). After loving that recipe so much and wanting to broaden my horizons, I tried this one. This is next-level and absolutely incredible. I can't wait to keep searching for more recipes! 

The only recipe swap I made was to use moose roast instead of pork. I have a lot of it around (thanks Alaska!) and it turned out well in the green chili recipe. I'm sure pork would be amazing too!

Wow, been a while since this recipe has been rated. ðŸ˜‚ Made this today without raisins and it was really very good. I made this before with Guajillos and Hatch chilis and it tastes different and just as good. This chili and oj combo as written gives this a beautiful flavor and fragrance. I will use maybe half of the oj next time. Stays in my Favorites!

This is so good. I mean, really good. I made it exactly as written except a few small tweaks. I cubed the meat before browning and did it in two batches. And I stewed the pork for around 3 1/2 to 4 hours. 
Went with flour tortillas instead of corn (just a preference) and shredded some cabbage for a little texture and crunch. This is a recipe that requires time, but I really enjoy cooking and the end result is well worth it. Thanks so much for sharing!

We made this last night and it just might be the BEST thing we ever made. You get the perfect chili flavor with the right amount of sweetness that compliments the pork when combined, produces a deep savory flavor. I will be doubling it next time for sure. I really can`t tell you guys just how exceptional this is. Its one of those recipes that leaves you in disbelief of "Did I REALLY just make that at home?" Seriously, just make it and you will see what I am talking about. 

Kenji, thanks again for putting a satisfied smile on our face. I seriously have never encountered anyone more talented in the culinary world.
